Definition.WordDefinition: Wail \Wail\, v. t. [imp. & p. p. {Wailed}; p. pr. & vb. n. {Wailing}.] [OE. wailen, weilen, probably fr. Icel. v[ae]la; cf. Icel. v[ae], vei, woe, and E. wayment, also OE. wai, wei, woe. Cf. {Woe}.] To lament; to bewail; to grieve over; as, to wail one's death. --Shak. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Wail \Wail\, v. i. To express sorrow audibly; to make mournful outcry; to weep. [1913 Webster]
Therefore I will wail and howl. --Micah i. 8. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Wail \Wail\, n. Loud weeping; violent lamentation; wailing. ``The wail of the forest.'' --Longfellow. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Wail \Wail\, v. t. [Cf. Icel. val choice, velja to choose, akin to Goth. waljan, G. w["a]hlen.] To choose; to select. [Obs.] ``Wailed wine and meats.'' --Henryson. [1913 Webster]

wail n : a cry of sorrow and grief; "their pitiful laments could be heard throughout the ward" [syn: {lament}, {lamentation}, {plaint}] v 1: emit long loud cries; "wail in self-pity"; "howl with sorrow" [syn: {howl}, {ululate}, {roar}, {yawl}] 2: cry weakly or softly; "she wailed with pain" [syn: {whimper}, {mewl}, {pule}]
